segment.source: 4706(S) A new trust was created to a domain.
segment.target: 4706(S) A new trust was created to a domain.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4706(S) A new trust was created to a domain.
segment.target: Describes security event 4706(S) A new trust was created to a domain.

segment.source: 4706(S): A new trust was created to a domain.
segment.target: 4706(S): A new trust was created to a domain.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates when a new trust was created to a domain.
segment.target: This event generates when a new trust was created to a domain.

segment.source: This event is generated only on domain controllers.
segment.target: This event is generated only on domain controllers.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “create domain trust” operation.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “create domain trust” operation.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “create domain trust” operation.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “create domain trust” operation.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Trusted Domain:
segment.target: Trusted Domain:

segment.source: Domain Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of new trusted domain.
segment.target: Domain Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of new trusted domain.

segment.source: Domain ID Type = SID: SID of new trusted domain.
segment.target: Domain ID Type = SID: SID of new trusted domain.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Trust Information:
segment.target: Trust Information:

segment.source: Trust Type Type = UInt32: the type of new trust.
segment.target: Trust Type Type = UInt32: the type of new trust.

segment.source: The following table contains possible values for this field:
segment.target: The following table contains possible values for this field:

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Attribute Value
segment.target: Attribute Value

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: TRUSTTYPEDOWNLEVEL
segment.target: TRUSTTYPEDOWNLEVEL

segment.source: The domain controller of the trusted domain is a computer running an operating system earlier than Windows 2000.
segment.target: The domain controller of the trusted domain is a computer running an operating system earlier than Windows 2000.

segment.source: TRUSTTYPEUPLEVEL
segment.target: TRUSTTYPEUPLEVEL

segment.source: The domain controller of the trusted domain is a computer running Windows 2000 or later.
segment.target: The domain controller of the trusted domain is a computer running Windows 2000 or later.

segment.source: TRUSTTYPEMIT
segment.target: TRUSTTYPEMIT

segment.source: The trusted domain is running a non-Windows, RFC4120-compliant Kerberos distribution.
segment.target: The trusted domain is running a non-Windows, RFC4120-compliant Kerberos distribution.

segment.source: This type of trust is distinguished in that (1) a SID is not required for the TDO, and (2) the default key types include the DES-CBC and DES-CRC encryption types (see RFC4120 section 8.1).
segment.target: This type of trust is distinguished in that (1) a SID is not required for the TDO, and (2) the default key types include the DES-CBC and DES-CRC encryption types (see RFC4120 section 8.1).

segment.source: TRUSTTYPEDCE
segment.target: TRUSTTYPEDCE

segment.source: The trusted domain is a DCE realm.
segment.target: The trusted domain is a DCE realm.

segment.source: Historical reference, this value is not used in Windows.
segment.target: Historical reference, this value is not used in Windows.

segment.source: Trust Direction Type = UInt32: the direction of new trust.
segment.target: Trust Direction Type = UInt32: the direction of new trust.

segment.source: The following table contains possible values for this field:
segment.target: The following table contains possible values for this field:

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Attribute Value
segment.target: Attribute Value

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: TRUSTDIRECTIONDISABLED
segment.target: TRUSTDIRECTIONDISABLED

segment.source: The trust relationship exists, but it has been disabled.
segment.target: The trust relationship exists, but it has been disabled.

segment.source: TRUSTDIRECTIONINBOUND
segment.target: TRUSTDIRECTIONINBOUND

segment.source: The trusted domain trusts the primary domain to perform operations such as name lookups and authentication.
segment.target: The trusted domain trusts the primary domain to perform operations such as name lookups and authentication.

segment.source: TRUSTDIRECTIONOUTBOUND
segment.target: TRUSTDIRECTIONOUTBOUND

segment.source: The primary domain trusts the trusted domain to perform operations such as name lookups and authentication.
segment.target: The primary domain trusts the trusted domain to perform operations such as name lookups and authentication.

segment.source: TRUSTDIRECTIONBIDIRECTIONAL
segment.target: TRUSTDIRECTIONBIDIRECTIONAL

segment.source: Both domains trust one another for operations such as name lookups and authentication.
segment.target: Both domains trust one another for operations such as name lookups and authentication.

segment.source: Trust Attributes Type = UInt32: the decimal value of attributes for new trust.
segment.target: Trust Attributes Type = UInt32: the decimal value of attributes for new trust.

segment.source: You need convert decimal value to hexadecimal and find it in the table below.
segment.target: You need convert decimal value to hexadecimal and find it in the table below.

segment.source: The following table contains possible values for this field:
segment.target: The following table contains possible values for this field:

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Attribute Value
segment.target: Attribute Value

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: TRUSTATTRIBUTENONTRANSITIVE
segment.target: TRUSTATTRIBUTENONTRANSITIVE

segment.source: If this bit is set, then the trust cannot be used transitively.
segment.target: If this bit is set, then the trust cannot be used transitively.

segment.source: For example, if domain A trusts domain B, which in turn trusts domain C, and the AB trust has this attribute set, then a client in domain A cannot authenticate to a server in domain C over the ABC trust linkage.
segment.target: For example, if domain A trusts domain B, which in turn trusts domain C, and the AB trust has this attribute set, then a client in domain A cannot authenticate to a server in domain C over the ABC trust linkage.

segment.source: TRUSTATTRIBUTEUPLEVELONLY
segment.target: TRUSTATTRIBUTEUPLEVELONLY

segment.source: If this bit is set in the attribute, then only Windows 2000 operating system and newer clients may use the trust link.
segment.target: If this bit is set in the attribute, then only Windows 2000 operating system and newer clients may use the trust link.

segment.source: Netlogon does not consume trust objects that have this flag set.
segment.target: Netlogon does not consume trust objects that have this flag set.

segment.source: TRUSTATTRIBUTEQUARANTINEDDOMAIN
segment.target: TRUSTATTRIBUTEQUARANTINEDDOMAIN

segment.source: If this bit is set, the trusted domain is quarantined and is subject to the rules of SID Filtering as described in MS-PAC section 4.1.2.2.
segment.target: If this bit is set, the trusted domain is quarantined and is subject to the rules of SID Filtering as described in MS-PAC section 4.1.2.2.

segment.source: TRUSTATTRIBUTEFORESTTRANSITIVE
segment.target: TRUSTATTRIBUTEFORESTTRANSITIVE

segment.source: If this bit is set, the trust link is a cross-forest trustMS-KILE between the root domains of two forests, both of which are running in a forest functional level of DSBEHAVIORWIN2003 or greater.
segment.target: If this bit is set, the trust link is a cross-forest trustMS-KILE between the root domains of two forests, both of which are running in a forest functional level of DSBEHAVIORWIN2003 or greater.

segment.source: Only evaluated on Windows Server 2003 operating system, Windows Server 2008 operating system, Windows Server 2008 R2 operating system, Windows Server 2012 operating system, Windows Server 2012 R2 operating system, and Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview operating system.
segment.target: Only evaluated on Windows Server 2003 operating system, Windows Server 2008 operating system, Windows Server 2008 R2 operating system, Windows Server 2012 operating system, Windows Server 2012 R2 operating system, and Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview operating system.

segment.source: Can only be set if forest and trusted forest are running in a forest functional level of DSBEHAVIORWIN2003 or greater.
segment.target: Can only be set if forest and trusted forest are running in a forest functional level of DSBEHAVIORWIN2003 or greater.

segment.source: TRUSTATTRIBUTECROSSORGANIZATION
segment.target: TRUSTATTRIBUTECROSSORGANIZATION

segment.source: If this bit is set, then the trust is to a domain or forest that is not part of the organization.
segment.target: If this bit is set, then the trust is to a domain or forest that is not part of the organization.

segment.source: The behavior controlled by this bit is explained in MS-KILE section 3.3.5.7.5 and MS-APDS section 3.1.5.
segment.target: The behavior controlled by this bit is explained in MS-KILE section 3.3.5.7.5 and MS-APDS section 3.1.5.

segment.source: Only evaluated on Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2012 R2, and Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview.
segment.target: Only evaluated on Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2012 R2, and Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview.

segment.source: Can only be set if forest and trusted forest are running in a forest functional level of DSBEHAVIORWIN2003 or greater.
segment.target: Can only be set if forest and trusted forest are running in a forest functional level of DSBEHAVIORWIN2003 or greater.

segment.source: TRUSTATTRIBUTEWITHINFOREST
segment.target: TRUSTATTRIBUTEWITHINFOREST

segment.source: If this bit is set, then the trusted domain is within the same forest.
segment.target: If this bit is set, then the trusted domain is within the same forest.

segment.source: Only evaluated on Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2012 R2, and Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview.
segment.target: Only evaluated on Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2012 R2, and Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview.

segment.source: TRUSTATTRIBUTETREATASEXTERNAL
segment.target: TRUSTATTRIBUTETREATASEXTERNAL

segment.source: If this bit is set, then a cross-forest trust to a domain is to be treated as an external trust for the purposes of SID Filtering.
segment.target: If this bit is set, then a cross-forest trust to a domain is to be treated as an external trust for the purposes of SID Filtering.

segment.source: Cross-forest trusts are more stringently filtered than external trusts.
segment.target: Cross-forest trusts are more stringently filtered than external trusts.

segment.source: This attribute relaxes those cross-forest trusts to be equivalent to external trusts.
segment.target: This attribute relaxes those cross-forest trusts to be equivalent to external trusts.

segment.source: For more information on how each trust type is filtered, see MS-PAC section 4.1.2.2.
segment.target: For more information on how each trust type is filtered, see MS-PAC section 4.1.2.2.

segment.source: Only evaluated on Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2012 R2, and Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview.
segment.target: Only evaluated on Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2012 R2, and Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview.

segment.source: Only evaluated if SID Filtering is used.
segment.target: Only evaluated if SID Filtering is used.

segment.source: Only evaluated on cross-forest trusts having TRUSTATTRIBUTEFORESTTRANSITIVE.
segment.target: Only evaluated on cross-forest trusts having TRUSTATTRIBUTEFORESTTRANSITIVE.

segment.source: Can only be set if forest and trusted forest are running in a forest functional level of DSBEHAVIORWIN2003 or greater.
segment.target: Can only be set if forest and trusted forest are running in a forest functional level of DSBEHAVIORWIN2003 or greater.

segment.source: TRUSTATTRIBUTEUSESRC4ENCRYPTION
segment.target: TRUSTATTRIBUTEUSESRC4ENCRYPTION

segment.source: This bit is set on trusts with the trustType set to TRUSTTYPEMIT, which are capable of using RC4 keys.
segment.target: This bit is set on trusts with the trustType set to TRUSTTYPEMIT, which are capable of using RC4 keys.

segment.source: Historically, MIT Kerberos distributions supported only DES and 3DES keys (RFC4120, RFC3961).
segment.target: Historically, MIT Kerberos distributions supported only DES and 3DES keys (RFC4120, RFC3961).

segment.source: MIT 1.4.1 adopted the RC4HMAC encryption type common to Windows 2000 MS-KILE, so trusted domains deploying later versions of the MIT distribution required this bit.
segment.target: MIT 1.4.1 adopted the RC4HMAC encryption type common to Windows 2000 MS-KILE, so trusted domains deploying later versions of the MIT distribution required this bit.

segment.source: For more information, see "Keys and Trusts", section 6.1.6.9.1.
segment.target: For more information, see "Keys and Trusts", section 6.1.6.9.1.

segment.source: Only evaluated on TRUSTTYPEMIT
segment.target: Only evaluated on TRUSTTYPEMIT

segment.source: TRUSTATTRIBUTECROSSORGANIZATIONNOTGTDELEGATION
segment.target: TRUSTATTRIBUTECROSSORGANIZATIONNOTGTDELEGATION

segment.source: If this bit is set, tickets granted under this trust MUST NOT be trusted for delegation.
segment.target: If this bit is set, tickets granted under this trust MUST NOT be trusted for delegation.

segment.source: The behavior controlled by this bit is as specified in MS-KILE section 3.3.5.7.5.
segment.target: The behavior controlled by this bit is as specified in MS-KILE section 3.3.5.7.5.

segment.source: Only supported on Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2012 R2, and Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview.
segment.target: Only supported on Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2012 R2, and Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview.

segment.source: TRUSTATTRIBUTEPIMTRUST
segment.target: TRUSTATTRIBUTEPIMTRUST

segment.source: If this bit and the TATE bit are set, then a cross-forest trust to a domain is to be treated as Privileged Identity Management trust for the purposes of SID Filtering.
segment.target: If this bit and the TATE bit are set, then a cross-forest trust to a domain is to be treated as Privileged Identity Management trust for the purposes of SID Filtering.

segment.source: For more information on how each trust type is filtered, see MS-PAC section 4.1.2.2.
segment.target: For more information on how each trust type is filtered, see MS-PAC section 4.1.2.2.

segment.source: Evaluated only on Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Evaluated only on Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: Evaluated only if SID Filtering is used.
segment.target: Evaluated only if SID Filtering is used.

segment.source: Evaluated only on cross-forest trusts having TRUSTATTRIBUTEFORESTTRANSITIVE.
segment.target: Evaluated only on cross-forest trusts having TRUSTATTRIBUTEFORESTTRANSITIVE.

segment.source: Can be set only if the forest and the trusted forest are running in a forest functional level of DSBEHAVIORWINTHRESHOLD or greater.
segment.target: Can be set only if the forest and the trusted forest are running in a forest functional level of DSBEHAVIORWINTHRESHOLD or greater.

segment.source: SID Filtering Type = UnicodeString: SID Filtering state for the new trust:
segment.target: SID Filtering Type = UnicodeString: SID Filtering state for the new trust:

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4706(S): A new trust was created to a domain.
segment.target: For 4706(S): A new trust was created to a domain.

segment.source: Any changes related to Active Directory domain trusts (especially creation of the new trust) must be monitored and alerts should be triggered.
segment.target: Any changes related to Active Directory domain trusts (especially creation of the new trust) must be monitored and alerts should be triggered.

segment.source: If this change was not planned, investigate the reason for the change.
segment.target: If this change was not planned, investigate the reason for the change.
